Dear MATTHEW KUZMA:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Rule variance
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12102
Section • (1) Upon the written request of an applicant or agency, the
Description department may grant a variance from an administrative
rule if the alternative proposed ensures that the health,
care, safety, protection, supervision, and needed services
of children are maintained, and that the alternative aligns
with the intent of the administrative rule.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A licensed foster home has been in non-compliance with licensing
rules since 2022 due to having a 2nd floor bedroom that does not
have a floor to ceiling wall or latchable door. A variance was
requested and approved however the CPA did not submit a new
variance request to document the non-compliance after the
previous variance expired.
Investigation Licensing worker was interviewed via telephone on June 6,
2024. She stated the Foster Placement has been licensed since
January 2021. She stated she has been assigned to the Foster
Placement file since January, 2022 and she did not complete the
initial home study. She stated when she was initially assigned to
the provider record, she was told there was a variance in place
due to not having a latchable door on one of the upstairs
bedrooms. The variance was requested for the duration the Foster
Placement license was open and it was her understanding the
agency had obtained an ongoing approval. In December, 2021
another variance was requested due to the number of children in
the home. The agency was going to withdraw that variance and
withdrew the wall and door variance by mistake. When the
variance was re-requested, they were told there could not be an
ongoing approval. It was recommended to use Family Incentive
Grant (FIG) funding and rectify the issue.
She stated the agency struggled to find contractors who were
willing to provide a quote for the work due to Foster Placement
living in a remote area. Initially, the Licensing Supervisor was
working with the Foster Placement to obtain a contractor quote.
More recently, the Foster Placement has been contacting
contractors and obtaining quotes. It took a while to obtain quotes,
but once they these, Licensing Worker sent them to FIG in
October, 2022. FIG provided approval in November, 2022.
2

Licensing Worker was on maternity leave from November, 2022
until February, 2023 and during that time another worker was
temporarily assigned. She attempted to contact the contractor with
the lowest quote one time after FIG approval due to going on
maternity leave. She spoke to him and had a positive interaction
and expected the process to move forward. Prior to going on
maternity leave she provided all information to her supervisor and
the two workers covering while she was on leave. When she
returned from maternity leave there were no updates given to her.
She stated no one attempted to contact the contractor and the
variance had lapsed. She stated she provided a detailed email
prior to leaving that the variance was set to expire on December
31, 2022. She was told the workers who were covering were going
to bring the variance to date and that did not happen. The
variance lapsed from December 31, 2022, until April 2023 when
she received the case back.
Upon being reassigned she attempted to resubmit the variance.
There were corrections that went back and forth but it was
eventually approved in July 2023. There was a lengthy delay due
to the contractor not responding to multiple attempts to gather
information/documentation needed to process payment.
Eventually she was given permission from FIG to move on to
another contractor that had submitted a quote, and that contractor
also did not respond or provide requested information. In October,
2023 Foster Placement received another quote. The contractor
indicated he would be interested in completing the work. A quote
was submitted to FIG on October 22, 2023, and it was approved
on October 31, 2023. Upon approval the contractor requested a
down payment. Licensing Worker contacted FIG on October 31,
2023, regarding the down payment and they indicated on
November 3, 2023, there was an issue with the proposal that was
submitted because it did not state “invoice”. The contractor was
contacted several times and eventually made the change, and it
was resubmitted on December 5, 2023. She did not hear back and
on January 3, 2024, she contacted the accounting person in her
office and asked if she could look on SIGMA to see if the payment
was issued to the contractor. The accounting person was able to
see that the 50% payment was issued to the contractor on
November 21, 2023. Upon learning that payment had already
been issued she stated she attempted to contact the contractor
multiple times and explained the payment was issued in
November and wanted a status update. The variance expired
again in January 2024.
3

A meeting was held with DCWL Central Office Consultant who
indicated she would speak with her supervisor to see about
getting this approved. She did not hear anything after this. On
February 7, 2024, licensing worker sent a letter to contractor
asking for him to contact her with a plan no later than February 27,
2024. On March 5, 2024, her office received the letter stamped
returned mail and a handwritten note that said “does not live here.
From now on mail will go in trash, hasn’t lived here in years”. That
was the address contractor used when signing up in SIGMA in
summer of 2023, his quote in October 2023 and his invoice after
that.
Eventually contact was made with the contractor on March 5,
2024. He admitted he lives in Indiana and has all along.
Contractor stated he was willing to do the work. He had been paid
approximately $650 and Licensing Worker pointed out he
accepted payment, so the work needs to be completed. After this,
she was unable to get in contact with him again. On April 19,
2024, she was advised by her Program Manager to write a letter
to contractor requesting the money back along with an invoice
written up by the accounting person in their office and there has
still been no contact with him. Middle to late March she advised
Foster Placement to start the process of looking for a contractor
again. Foster Placement reported they had contacted several
other contractors and scheduled appointments, but no one came
to those appointments.
Licensing Supervisor was interviewed via Teams on June 7,
2024. She stated the initial home study was completed in early
2022. An ongoing variance was approved early on due to an
upstairs bedroom not having a latchable door but was mistakenly
closed. When another variance was requested, the agency was
told by DCWL the variance would not be approved as ongoing and
there would be an expiration date. The variance had lapsed
effective December 31, 2022, while Licensing Worker was on
maternity leave, and she began working on it once she returned.
The worker who covered while Licensing Worker was out had not
completed it as requested. Another variance was requested in
May 2023 so there was a lapse during that timeframe.
Licensing Supervisor stated there is currently not a variance in
place. The most recent variance expired on January 8, 2024, and
another one was requested and has been pending since January
2024. She stated the agency and Foster Placement have
struggled to find a contractor who is willing to complete the work.
The Foster Placement resides in a rural area and there are limited
4

contractors. Eventually a contractor was found who agreed to
complete the work. A FIG payment was made to a contractor who
agreed to complete the work. He accepted partial payment but
has not completed the work and is not communicating with the
agency. The agency is working with Central Office to recoup the
money.
Licensing Supervisor acknowledged the agency could have been
more diligent to avoid the variance lapsing. The agency utilizes
outlook calendars to track due dates. Supervisors maintain a
spreadsheet for report due dates and each worker must update
their work plan which includes due dates. Each worker has their
own work plan that they manage, and it is reviewed during
monthly supervision. Supervisor takes this information and
ensures there is an outlook calendar entry with due dates.
Licensing Supervisor was focusing on reports but not variances.
She has since created a spreadsheet that includes variance due
dates and has sent outlook invitations for those due dates.
Division of Child Welfare Licensing Central Office Consultant
(DCWL Central Office Consultant) was interviewed via Teams
on June 17, 2024. She stated the initial variance request came in
sometime during the foster parent’s initial licensing process. The
variance was requested because the home was missing a wall
and a door in an upstairs bedroom. She said during the initial
consult they asked the agency if Foster Placement could complete
the work themselves. They were told Foster Placement works
often, and the work is complicated. She stated DCWL never
approved an ongoing variance. The variance requests always had
an end date and the agency continued to request extensions.
During COVID there was discussion regarding a lack of
contractors and high costs. The agency has repeatedly stated
they are unable to find contractors to complete work.
She stated the agency continued to insist the work could not be
completed and explained they have been unable to find a
contractor who is willing to complete the work. DCWL advised that
a contractor would need to be the one to make a statement
indicating the work would not be able to be completed. The
agency was advised to continue to try and find a contractor. The
work was recently completed by Foster Placement. The agency
submitted photos to DCWL Central Office Consultant as
verification.
DCWL Central Office Consultant stated DCWL does not track
open variances and due dates because there are too many with
5

different due dates. She stated tracking and ensuring a variance
does not lapse is the responsibility of the agencies.

Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance. Based on interviews and

and did not submit a timely request for an extension which
resulted in the variance lapsing on two occasions.
Conclusion Violation Established

Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
